Every copywriter’s pet peeve: “Send me the copies!” When I first joined advertising, I said it too. “Hey, I’ve written three copies for this campaign.” It sounded right because everyone around me said it. Then I learned something that felt like a secret handshake of the ad world: In copywriting, “copy” isn’t plural. It’s a mass noun that describes written content as a whole, like “music” or “art.” You don’t say “musics” or “arts,” right? Same rule applies here. ✅ Correct: “The copy for this ad is ready.” ❌ Wrong: “The copies for this ad are ready.” “Copies” means duplicates or printouts, not different ideas. So instead of saying “three copies,” say “three versions of copy” or “three ad copy variations.” Of course, digital marketing has made “ad copies” common slang, and most of us let it pass. But every copywriter flinches a little each time they hear it. Because good copy starts with knowing what copy really means. hashtag # Copywriting hashtag # AdvertisingLife hashtag # MarketingTips hashtag # CreativeCareers hashtag # WritersCommunity
